content.description: Best done in the fall with low humidity, wind and lower temperatures. Good Luck!
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. If set up correctly, one rope can cover Buzzard also.
content.location: Between Snoopy and Buzzard. Hard bouldery start takes you to 2 pockets that are close together. Then thin moves, to more thin moves...

content.description: A nice way to occupy your time while waiting for your friends to arrive.
content.protection: This traverse stays close to the ground, no protection needed.
content.location: Start on the right side of the cave and traverse right. Go as far as you want, then traverse back to the cave.

content.description: Can be climbed on brittle pockets out right or more fun, but slightly more challenging face on the left.
content.protection: Anchors and treesDo not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: To the right of Double Layback Crack

content.description: White slightly overhanging face.
content.protection: TR / Gear.
content.location: Left side of the arete that has Keyhole Crack.

content.description: Same start as SALLY + DON. Use the letters. Reach up high to finish. Being tall is an advantage.
content.protection: Top rope, anchorsDo not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: About 6’ right of Flakes, SALLY + DON is carved in the rock, about 10’ off the ground.

content.description: High traverse tending left of the crack.
content.protection: Strategically placed climbing pad(s) would be a good idea.
content.location: Start on the left side of the crack staying high. The feet of "Tall Man" consist of the hands that are typical on "Smart Woman."

content.description: There are three variations, all Hinkley classics. Each has its own personality. Up and Left is hard. Up and Right is harder. Up and Up (straight) is somewhere in-between.
content.protection:
Top Rope, anchors. If set up correctly, one rope can cover all three Snoopy routes.

Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.

Note (June 2020): Rap rings and quicklinks have been stolen from route. If anyone has any information on who stole the hardware please contact the Cleveland Metroparks Police at 440.331.5530.

In the mean time, if you wish to use the bolt anchors:As always, inspect them carefully before use. Look for any damage that may have been caused during the theft of the hardware.As always, do not Top Rope directly off the bolts. Use your own equipment such as quickdraws.When cleaning the route, please either rap off the bolts after removing your gear, or reverse the process you used when setting up the route (Please do not lower directly on the bolts)
content.location: Start about 15’ right from And Now for Something Completely Different(all three Snoopy routes start in the same place). Go straight up through Snoopy’s ear, then go right through some very thin moves requiring precision footwork.One more set of moves takes you to a good ledge, where it is wise to traverse left back to your sling anchor.

content.description: There are three variations, all Hinkley classics. Each has its own personality. Up and Left is hard. Up and Right is harder. Up and Up (straight) is somewhere in-between.
content.protection:
Top Rope, anchors. If set up correctly, one rope can cover all three Snoopy routes.

Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.

Note (June 2020): Rap rings and quicklinks have been stolen from route. If anyone has any information on who stole the hardware please contact the Cleveland Metroparks Police at 440.331.5530.

In the mean time, if you wish to use the bolt anchors:As always, inspect them carefully before use. Look for any damage that may have been caused during the theft of the hardware.As always, do not Top Rope directly off the bolts. Use your own equipment such as quickdraws.When cleaning the route, please either rap off the bolts after removing your gear, or reverse the process you used when setting up the route (Please do not lower directly on the bolts)
content.location: Start about 15’ right from And Now for Something Completely Different(all three Snoopy routes start in the same place). Go straight up through Snoopy’s ear, then keep going straight up to the top; using holds from Snoopy right with your right hand and Snoopy with your left hand.

content.description: There are three variations, all Hinkley classics. Each has its own personality. Trending left is hard, trending right is harder. Ignoring either and going straight up is the hardest.
content.protection: Top Rope, anchors.
content.location: Start about 15’ right from And Now for Something Completely Different (all three Snoopy routes start in the same place). Go straight up through Snoopy’s ear and choose your direction.

content.description: Solid V2. Low traverse trending left of the crack.
content.protection: This traverse stays close to the ground, no protection needed.
content.location: Start low on the left side of the crack and work your way left, avoiding the huge "jugs" above you.

content.description: Short.
content.protection: TR.
content.location: To the right of the Keyhole Crack is a blank looking face with a few slot like holds on it.

content.description: Same start as Flakes. With hands on top of the flake start traversing right to a vertical 2’ slot about 4’ above and slightly left of the S in SALLY. Move across this slot and reach up right to finish.
content.protection:
Top Rope, anchors.

Note: Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: About 6’ right of Flakes, SALLY + DON is carved in the rock, about 10’ off the ground.

content.description: A nice flowing route using the right side of the crack as an arete.
content.protection: A TR can be set up utilizing the Maple tree above and to the right of The Crack. Several routes can be climbed from this tree.
content.location: Use the right side of The Crack as an arete. As long as one hand stays on the arete, anything to the right is on. Do not use the left side of the crack.

content.description: Well named.
content.protection: TR
content.location: Between the carving “SALLY + DON” and Double Layback Crack. Towards the top, reach for the sky!

content.description: Fun climb.
content.protection: AnchorsDo not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: To the right of You Break It, You Break It,  furthest route on the same unified cliff.

content.description: No specific crux, fun climb regardless.
content.protection:
Top Rope, anchors.

Note: Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: Route right of Hate Route.  Locate an 8” feature that looks like South America, about 10’ off the ground. The climb wanders through here.

content.description: Some unusual moves using the left side of the crack as an arete.
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. If set up correctly, one rope can cover When You Dance & Buzzard.    This can also be set up using less slings by utilizing the Maple tree above and to the right of The Crack. There is a swing if you come off, and it is hard top get back on the route if you are working it.
content.location: Use the left side of The Crack as an arete. As long as one hand stays on the arete, anything to the left is on. Do not use the right side of the crack.

content.description: The whole of the Land Arete.
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Left if cave at main wall

content.description: Behind the tree in this photo. Plainly obvious in person.
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Main wall, right of The Crack, just North of and left of the cave and offwidth.

content.description: Climb only the face avoiding The Land Arete Left off.
content.protection: Top rooe
content.location: Left of the large offwidth at the cave, right of Beyond Patagonia. “Next line”.

content.description: Mostly blank and slightly slabby face to the left of the crack
content.protection: Top rope from bolts
content.location: Start is the same as for Keyhole Crack. Traverse left at first ledge to blank and slightly slabby face to the left of the crack. Left arete and crack edge are off. Start ascent of face using low left undercling and shallow slot to the right (at about shoulder height). Lots of lichen=slippery! Better hands on the way up. Top out using “slopers” on upper ledge and mantling.

content.description: Obvious crack the splits the upper part of the wall. Towards the top of the crack there is a keyhole looking feature.
content.protection: Top Rope, anchors.Note: Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: Right around the corner from Tina Turner.

content.description: Several climbers have said “I hate this route”. It may go well one day and be trouble the next, until dialed. Nice variation with unique moves.
content.protection: A TR can be set up utilizing the Maple tree above and to the right of The Crack. Several routes can be climbed from this tree.
content.location: Same start as Burnout. After the start, go straight up avoiding the Burnout holds.

content.description: Short but spicy.
content.protection: Top Rope from the large Maple tree at the top of the route.
content.location: First route on Main Wall. Walk down the stairs until you see “JC Bidle” carved into the wall on your left, about eye level. Start just right of this. You should see the initials J.B.N. carved into the rock about  8’  above the ground. There is a large Maple tree that marks the top of the route.

content.description: Short, fun climb.
content.protection: Top Rope
content.location: To the right of Slots is rock with many groove like features in it.

content.description: Fun short climb.
content.protection: Top Rope, anchorsDo not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location:
Start about eight feet right of the edge of the cave area. Go up to a large horizontal hold that continues to cling to the wall somehow. Move left carefully past this hold to the flake/crack system on the upper part of the wall. 

  A sharp direct start begins directly under the flake/crack system. 

  Another harder variation is called Patterns, just to the left of Flakes.

content.description: Making sure your gear stays in the crux if you lead it .. otherwise it is smooth sailing.
content.protection: Originally done with stoppers. Anchors.Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: Obvious double crack to the right of Reach for the Sky.

content.description: Crux varies for everyone until you have it dialed. A Hinckley Classic.
content.protection: TR or Gear. A TR can be set up utilizing the Maple tree above and to the right of The Crack. Several routes can be climbed from this tree.
content.location: If you're walking along the prominent cliff, this is the Hinckley Crack / Crack ... you cannot miss it.

content.description: Sweet problem / TR. The erosion has taken the ground and lowered it ~one foot.. your mileage may vary on getting started. Originally done via a running jump to the suit case handle. May need cleaning before climbing.
content.protection: Pads / Spotters or a Rope (Ideally a double rope system.)
content.location: To the right of Patagonia the wall has a large split. To the right of the split is a small “cave". Start the climb under where the crack splits the top part of the wall. One start is to stand on the rock to the left of the two slots under the roof, reach up and start in the slot. It’s not over after the roof is pulled.

content.description: A low crux takes you to the thin but classic moves of Buzzard.
content.protection: Top Rope, anchors.Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: Immediately left of the Crack. Crack is off. Avoid the obvious 5” hole in the wall. Climb between the 5” hole and the crack to start, then finish on Buzzard.

content.description: Another Hinckley classic.
content.protection: Top Rope, anchors.Note: Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: Left of the Crack. Crack is off. Start by heading straight for obvious 5” hole in the wall. Use the hole and go slightly right, then straight up. Remember to stay out of the crack!

content.description: Well named. A Hinckley Classic.
content.protection: A TR can be set up utilizing the Maple tree above and to the right of The Crack. Several routes can be climbed from this tree.
content.location: The right side of the prominent crack.

content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Next line of climbing after Beyond Patagonia

content.description: Great climbing, however it is wet most of the year due to water seepage from a seam about 3/4 of the way up the route. If it’s dry, jump on it while you can. The name comes from a banana shaped feature about 1/2 way up the wall.
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. If set up correctly, one rope can cover the three Banana routes and And Now for Something Completely Different.
content.location: Starts about 7’ right from J.B.N.  Head straight up for a few moves then angle right until you are above and slightly left of the banana shaped feature. Crux move takes you to the top.

content.description: Great climbing, however it is wet most of the year due to water seepage from a seam about 3/4 of the way up the route. If it’s dry, jump on it while you can. The name comes from a banana shaped feature about 1/2 way up the wall.
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. If set up correctly, one rope can cover the three Banana routes and And Now for Something Completely Different.
content.location: Starts about 6’ right of Banana Left. Go straight up and then slightly right from the banana shaped feature to harder moves.

content.description: Great climbing, however it is wet most of the year due to water seepage from a seam about 3/4 of the way up the route. If it’s dry, jump on it while you can. The name comes from a banana shaped feature about 1/2 way up the wall.
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. If set up correctly, one rope can cover the three Banana routes and And Now for Something Completely Different.
content.location: Same start as Banana Center. At the Banana shaped feature traverse right several feet to a whale shaped feature. A final hard move takes you to the top.

climbs.name: And Now For Something Completely Different

content.description: Bouldery start to thin moves.
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. If set up correctly, one rope can cover this and the three Banana routes.
content.location: Start about 8’ from the Banana. A bouldery start takes you to thin moves to a whale shaped feature. Finish on Banana

content.description: Lower half is smoother, upper has pockets.
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Next Routes just beyond Patagonia.

content.description: Main Cliff Area with the highest concentration of quality Top Rope routes.
